item.title: India Central Bank Lowers Key Rate to 5.5% in Surprise Move
item.description: India’s central bank surprised with a bigger-than-expected interest rate cut to boost the economy, as trade uncertainties cloud growth prospects.
item.dc:creator: Anup Roy, Prateek Mazumdar

media:content.media:description: RBI Governor Sanjay Malhotra Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: US Treasury Calls on BOJ to Hike Rates to Correct Yen Weakness
item.description: The US Treasury called on the Bank of Japan to raise interest rates to strengthen the yen, stepping much deeper into policy recommendations for Tokyo than before in its semiannual currency report.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

media:content.media:description: The Bank of Japan (BOJ) headquarters in Tokyo, Japan, on Thursday, May 1. The BOJ left its benchmark rate unchanged while pushing back the timing for when it expects to reach its inflation target amid intensified uncertainties due to US tariff measures.

item.title: Trump’s $12 Billion Tourism Wipeout
item.description: Four months into the president’s second term, his policies are upending tourism worldwide.
item.dc:creator: K Oanh Ha, Dorothy Gambrell

item.title: Starmer's Stock-Market Apathy Is Bad for Growth
item.description: It’s been another bad week for London’s status as a listing venue. A shame, then, that recent government policy has focused on private markets investing.
item.dc:creator: Chris Hughes

media:content.media:description: LEIGH ON SEA, ENGLAND - NOVEMBER 4: A closed sign hangs on the door window against a British Union Jack flag on a cafe in Old Leigh on November 4, 2024 in Leigh-on-Sea, United Kingdom. (Photo by John Keeble/Getty Images)

item.title: Poland’s Kotecki Says MPC Is Turning Cautious on Further Easing
item.description: Polish policymakers are turning increasingly cautious toward further interest-rate cuts due to growing political instability and concern over a bloated budget, central banker Ludwik Kotecki said.
item.dc:creator: Agnieszka Barteczko

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers on the skyline near the Witokrzyski Bridge in Warsaw, Poland, on Tuesday, April 2, 2024. Polish inflation fell to the central bank’s target for the first time in three years in March even as policymakers are expected to keep interest rates steady due to concerns over resurgent price growth later in 2024. Photographer: Damian Lemanski/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan, US Start Tariff Talks Amid Reports on Cars, Rare Earths
item.description: Japan and the US have begun the latest round of trade negotiations, with media reports suggesting Tokyo’s delegation is trying to win a reprieve from the tariffs by pledging to make more cars in the US and enhancing cooperation on rare earths.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Honda vehicles bound for shipment at a port in Yokohama.

item.title: Economists Slash Singapore GDP, CPI Growth Forecasts on Tariffs
item.description: Economists have cut growth forecasts for Singapore’s gross domestic product and consumer prices as uncertainties of the global trade war leave the Lion City vulnerable to risks.
item.dc:creator: Cynthia Li

item.title: Russia on Cusp of First Rate Cut Since 2022 as Inflation Eases
item.description: Russia’s central bank is on the cusp of the first interest-rate cut in three years, as easing inflation opens the door to relief for an economy struggling under the weight of high borrowing costs.
item.dc:creator: Anthony Halpin

media:content.media:description: The Russian Central Bank headquarters in Moscow.

item.title: South Korea to Keep Discussing Forex With US After Currency List
item.description: South Korea will continue to discuss its foreign exchange policy with the US to promote mutual understanding, after the Treasury kept the Asian ally on its watchlist and called for curbing currency intervention.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin

media:content.media:description: South Korean 50,000 won banknotes. Photographer: SeongJoon Cho/Bloomberg

item.title: Trump and Carney in Talks on Trade Ahead of G-7 Summit
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Canadian Prime Minister Mark Carney have been in direct contact trying to reach a trade deal, but the two sides still have work to do to find agreement, according to people familiar with the discussions.
item.dc:creator: Brian Platt

media:content.media:description: Mark Carney, Canada's incoming prime minister, speaks at an ArcelorMittal Dofasco steel facility in Hamilton, Ontario, Canada, on Wednesday, March 12, 2025. Canada will keep its trade retaliation in place until the US lifts its own tariffs and commits to free trade, said Carney, who will succeed Justin Trudeau as Canada’s prime minister within days.

item.title: Japan’s Early May Exports Drop as Tariff War Upends Commerce
item.description: Japan’s exports fell in the first 20 days of May as the Trump administration’s sweeping tariffs continued to disrupt trade.
item.dc:creator: Yoshiaki Nohara

media:content.media:description: Vehicles bound for shipment at the Port of Nagoya. Photographer: Toru Hanai/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan’s Household Spending Falls in Blow for Shrinking Economy
item.description: Japan’s household spending unexpectedly declined in April as elevated inflation deterred discretionary spending, in a worrisome sign for policymakers after the economy began contracting even before US tariff measures fully kicked in.
item.dc:creator: Toru Fujioka

item.title: Bond Traders Look to US Jobs Report for Signals of Fed Rate Path
item.description: Bond traders will dissect the May jobs report for any signs of a softening labor market as they gauge the timing of Federal Reserve interest-rate cuts.
item.dc:creator: Ye Xie

item.title: US Companies Likely Held Onto Workers in May Despite Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: US hiring likely moderated further in May and the unemployment rate was little changed, suggesting employers are yet to implement big changes to their headcount in response to President Donald Trump’s trade policy.
item.dc:creator: Augusta Saraiva

media:content.media:description: A worker at a metals factory in California. Photographer: David Paul Morris/Bloomberg

item.title: US Deficit Is a ‘Ticking Time Bomb,’ Citadel Securities President Says
item.description: Citadel Securities President Jim Esposito said the US deficit and mounting government debt levels are a “ticking time bomb,” adding his voice to the chorus of financial executives soundings warnings about America’s deteriorating fiscal outlook.
item.dc:creator: Katherine Doherty, Bernard Goyder

media:content.media:description: The US Capitol in Washington, DC, US, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. US House Speaker Mike Johnson said he is fighting to maintain the new $40,000 cap on state and local deductions in the draft tax bill now before the Senate, where Republicans are seeking to enact a less generous break.

item.title: Taiwan’s Money-Market Rate Slump May Delay Central Bank Easing
item.description: A surge in the Taiwanese dollar last month spurred an influx of funds, driving local money-market rates to the lowest level in more than a year and potentially delaying monetary easing by the central bank.
item.dc:creator: Chien-Hua Wan

item.title: Candidate for Bank of Thailand Chief Backs Aggressive Rate Cuts
item.description: Thailand should be more aggressive in cutting borrowing costs given its bleak growth outlook and subdued inflation, according to Somprawin Manprasert, one of the candidates seeking to become the Bank of Thailand’s new governor.
item.dc:creator: Suttinee Yuvejwattana

item.title: Lagarde Steels for Battles Ahead After ECB Hits Sweet Spot
item.description: Christine Lagarde just unveiled an outlook that may be as good it gets for the euro zone.
item.dc:creator: Zoe Schneeweiss, Craig Stirling, Alice Gledhill

media:content.media:description: Luis de Guindos, vice president of the European Central Bank (ECB), left, and Christine Lagarde, president of the European Central Bank (ECB), at a rates decision news conference in Frankfurt, Germany, on Thursday, June 5, 2025. The ECB lowered interest rates for the eighth time in a year after inflation dipped beneath 2% and the economy suffered repeated blows from US tariffs.

item.title: Lagarde Determined to Finish ECB Term After WEF Speculation
item.description: Christine Lagarde pledged to see out her presidency at the European Central Bank following speculation over an early departure to lead the World Economic Forum in Switzerland.
item.dc:creator: Mark Schroers, William Horobin

media:content.media:description: Christine Lagarde

item.title: Businesses Expect to Pass Along 50% of Tariffs, Fed Survey Finds
item.description: Business expect to pass through roughly half of tariff-related expenses to US consumers still reeling from the pandemic-era inflation surge, according to a new survey from the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta.
item.dc:creator: Jonnelle Marte

media:content.media:description: Shoppers browse shirts at a clothing store in Atlanta, Georgia.

item.title: Asia Sees Trump’s 5%-of-GDP Defense Spending Goal as Unrealistic
item.description: US President Donald Trump’s push for Indo-Pacific allies to ramp up military spending to counter growing threats from the likes of China and North Korea is running into the hard reality of fiscal limits and jittery bond markets.
item.dc:creator: Philip Heijmans, Swati Pandey

item.title: Chile’s Leftist Presidential Hopefuls Open Door to Higher Taxes
item.description: Chile’s leftist presidential hopefuls Jeannette Jara and Gonzalo Winter said on Thursday that if elected they would raise some taxes to help keep a lid on a fiscal debt.
item.dc:creator: Matthew Malinowski

media:content.media:description: Jeannette Jara, presidential candidate for the Communist Party of Chile, speaks after registering her candidacy at the Electoral Service of Chile in Santiago, Chile.

item.title: Trump, Xi Agree to More Trade Talks as Rare Earths Dispute Cools
item.description: US President Donald Trump and Chinese President Xi Jinping on Thursday agreed to further trade talks aimed at resolving disputes over tariffs and supplies of rare earth minerals at the heart of tensions between the world’s two largest economies.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Lucey, Akayla Gardner

media:content.media:description: Donald Trump and Xi Jinping

item.title: Fed’s Kugler Says Her Main Focus Now Is Inflation
item.description: Federal Reserve Governor Adriana Kugler said her main focus now is inflation, rather than a potential slowdown in economic growth, as President Donald Trump’s tariff policies threaten to put upward pressure on prices.
item.dc:creator: Amara Omeokwe

media:content.media:description: Adriana Kugler, member of the Board of Governors of the US Federal Reserve, speaks on the economy in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Feb. 7, 2024. Kugler presented an optimistic case for a continued slowdown in US inflation while indicating there is little urgency to reduce the Fed's benchmark lending rate soon.

item.title: Mauritius Plans Temporary Tax Hikes to Stabilize Public Finances
item.description: Mauritius will temporarily raise taxes on individuals and corporations and cut spending on some social programs to shore up revenue and stabilize public finances.
item.dc:creator: Kamlesh Bhuckory, Prinesha Naidoo

media:content.media:description: Residential buildings in Port Louis, Mauritius. Photographer: GIANLUIGI GUERCIA/AFP

item.title: Schmid Says Fed Needs Flexibility Given Great Tariff Uncertainty
item.description: Federal Reserve Bank of Kansas City President Jeff Schmid said he and his colleagues will need to be nimble as they assess how tariffs will impact the economy.
item.dc:creator: Catarina Saraiva

media:content.media:description: A freight train crosses into El Paso, Texas, US, on an international railroad bridge at the US-Mexico border in Juarez, Chihuahua state, Mexico, on Thursday, April 3, 2025. President Donald Trump is imposing tariffs on US trading partners worldwide, his biggest assault yet on a global economic system he has long bemoaned as unfair.

item.title: Chicago’s Dire Finances Hold It Back in Competition Among Cities
item.description: The obstacles to economic growth in the third-largest US city have rarely looked so numerous and intractable.
item.dc:creator: Shruti Singh

item.title: ECB Watching for Tariff-Policy Impact on Economy, Escriva Says
item.description: European Central Bank Governing Council member Jose Luis Escriva said policymakers are carefully watching the impact of US tariffs on the euro-area economy.

item.title: EU Launches Tool to Monitor Trade Diversion From Trump Tariffs
item.description: The European Commission has formally launched a surveillance tool to monitor any trade diversion resulting from US President Donald Trump’s tariffs, as initial results revealed a surge of imports in many goods.
